abstracts.cdata!:
The audit gives mixed ratings: the
            project outcome is downgraded to moderately satisfactory
            from a satisfactory rating by the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR), while sustainability is rated as non-evaluable
            by this audit, as opposed to a likely rating by the ICR;
            yet, it concurs on a modest rating for the institutional
            development impact, and satisfactory performances by the
            Bank and Borrower. Project design, particularly in countries
            with low capacity, should be taken carefully: specifically,
            the time needed for the reform process to achieve results
            should receive special attention, and it may be prudent to
            seek progress in small incremental steps. Moreover, given
            privatized road maintenance may yield significant benefits
            for the road sector in low-income developing countries, it
            was demonstrated by the project that difficulties will
            occur, and, provided the steps necessary to implement the
            transition in such environment. Effective Road Funds need
            adequate revenue, independence, and an effective governance
            structure. Because income from user fees is often
            insufficient to cover maintenance needs, an additional
            government contribution is suggested as necessary.
